publications: [{"title":"A Machine Learning-based approach to Predict Corrosion Allowance for Ships","subtitle":"International Society of Offshore and Polar Engineers","date":"June 10, 2018","description":"Corrosion in seagoing vessels is an unavoidable phenomenon which affects the physical life and safety of the hull structures. Conventionallycorrosion margins are introduced to cope with the problems of corrosion and wear. Since the phenomena of corrosion and wear of structural hull members are the consequences of extremely complex processes governed by many factors, it is necessary to establish corrosion marginsand permissible corrosion levels by sufficiently taking into account the past records. This paper presents machine learning-based methods tomodel corrosion allowance in ships based on past data. It is seen that machine learning models can predict the level of corrosion for ships of a particular type (in the present work, bulk carrier) given the factors such as age, location, structural members' function, type of coating etc. Based on a comparative study using various learning algorithms like Neural Nets, Support Vectors, and Ensemble Learning, it is observed that corrosion can be predicted within acceptable range of accuracy for the selected ships."}]

projects.title: Emotion Recognition using Machine learning algorithms
projects.description: Â•Using various tools and techniques for Music Information Retrieval (MIR) and Machine learning for predicting audience response.Â•Exploring the different dimensions of Hindustani Music responsible for evoking a variety of cognitive and emotive responses through "audience response".Â•Understanding the principles which govern the generation of meaning and effect in Indian ragas by the way they are experienced and interpreted by listeners.

projects.title: Studying the mode-shapes of a CFFF plate in vibration
projects.description: Â•Investigating the mode-shapes of a Clamped-Free-Free-Free plate in partially or fully submerged condition.Â•The hydrodynamics was studied by numerical analysis using the dipole distribution technique in Ansys.Â•The natural frequencies of the cantilever plate surrounded in a fluid medium were calculated and verified experimentally and through various published papers.Â•Experimental verification of the property of added mass being frequency independent.Verifying experimentally that the diffraction force is completely in phase with the acceleration for vibrating bodies i.e at high frequencies.
